headline.main: Ferrer, His Candidacy Assured, Campaigns in Brooklyn

byline.original: By NICHOLAS CONFESSORE and FERNANDA SANTOS; Winnie Hu contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: Fernando Ferrer began the first real weekend of the general election campaign quietly shoring up support among backers of his former rivals for the Democratic nomination, while Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg continued efforts to make inroads into Mr. Ferrer's own base of Hispanic voters. Making his first weekend appearance as the de facto Democratic nominee, Mr. Ferrer wore a striped button-down shirt, khaki pants and sturdy shoes for a trip to a Brooklyn farmer's market -- one situated, not coincidentally, in Park Slope, a bastion of support for Congressman Anthony D. Weiner, the second-place finisher in last week's primary.''I need your help in November,'' Mr. Ferrer told some of the well-wishers who stopped to shake his hand as he strolled past stands selling organic hot peppers and apple-and-sage sausages, staples of the Prospect Park Greenmarket and favorites among its brownstone clientele.
docs.snippet: Fernando Ferrer began the first real weekend of the general election campaign quietly shoring up support among backers of his former rivals for the Democratic nomination.
